posts.title: NorthBay Joins the New AWS Public Sector Partner Program
posts.text:
23 NorthBay Joins the New AWS Public Sector Partner Program Being one of the first Amazon Web Services (AWS) Partner Network (APN) Consulting Partners to join the AWS Public Sector Partner Program further validates NorthBay's expertise with AWS services for government, non-profit and education customers 
* Awards ANDOVER, Mass.   NorthBay (http://www.northbaysolutions.com), an Amazon Web Services (AWS) Partner Network (APN) Advanced Consulting Partner focused cloud big data and mobile development services, today announces it has joined the new AWS Public Sector Partner Program. The AWS Public Sector Partner Program recognizes partners with solutions and experience in delivering government, education, and non-profit customer mission around the world.NorthBay has been an APN Advanced Consulting Partner (http://www.aws-partner-directory.com/Name=NorthBay+Solutions%2C+LLC) for some time and is one of the first companies to achieve acceptance into the program.NorthBay is long been helping both profit and non-profit companies implement cloud-based data lake and data warehouse solutions. "We are excited to be one of the first APN Consulting Partners selected to be part of the AWS Public Sector Partner Program," said Brian Barker, CEO at NorthBay. "This recognition and achievement further demonstrates the success of NorthBay and AWS working together to successfully craft and implement highly complex data solutions that leverage the key AWS services."The AWS Public Sector Partner Program recognizes partners with solutions and experience in delivering government, education, and non-profit customer mission around the world. APN Partners can qualify for the Public Sector Partner Program by having a strong overall AWS practice and demonstrating their experience and readiness to support government, education, and/or non-profit customer mission NorthBay and Amazon Web Services are working together to intensely focus on helping customers build and deploy data pipeline services in the cloud at scale About NorthBay NorthBay is a global provider of big data software and mobile and solutions that leverage Amazon Web Services. The company specializes in the architecture and development of solutions for clients in markets that include media, financial services, healthcare, life science, education, publishing advertising and mobile gaming. In five short years, NorthBay has organically grown to 200 people worldwide. For more information visit www.northbaysolutions.com or call 617-433-9221. Media Contact

thread.section_title: Amazon Employee Attempts Suicide After Sending Email to Colleagues – Fortune
thread.title: Amazon Employee Attempts Suicide After Sending Email to Colleagues
thread.title_full: Amazon Employee Attempts Suicide After Sending Email to Colleagues

posts.author: Madeline Farber
posts.title: Amazon Employee Attempts Suicide After Sending Email to Colleagues
posts.text:
An Amazon employee jumped from a building at the company’s Seattle headquarters after reportedly sending a disgruntled email to CEO Jeff Bezos and hundreds of his co-workers.
The man, whose name is currently not public, survived the 12-story fall. He was critically injured and taken to a local hospital shortly after, Bloomberg first reported. Police reported the incident as a suicide attempt.
Prior to the incident, the man requested for a transfer to a different department within the company, Bloomberg reports. Instead, however, he was placed on an “employee improvement plan”--a step that could result in his termination from Amazon amzn if his performance didn’t improve, notes Bloomberg.
 
In the email, the man reportedly criticized the company’s handling of his transfer request and “hinted that he might harm himself,” a person familiar with the matter told Bloomberg.
"Our thoughts are with our colleague as he continues to recover," an Amazon spokesperson told Fortune in a statement, who declined to comment on the matter further. "He's receiving some of the best care possible and we will be there to support him throughout the recovery process.”

posts.title: The Bay: Amazon Releases Season Two of Drama Series
posts.text:
The Bay: Amazon Releases Season Two of Drama Series by Cindy McLennan, November 29, 2016 
Good news, soap fans. The second season of digital drama, The Bay , premieres today on Amazon . Check out the season two trailer, after the jump. An online soap opera set in Bay City, The Bay was created by Gregori J. Martin. 
Kristos Andrews, Mary Beth Evans, Derrell Whitt, Jade Harlow, Taylor Stanley, Tristan Rogers, Lilly Melgar, Ronn Moss, and Matthew Ashford star. The Bay won the Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Digital Series. Evans and Andrews also won the outstanding performer awards. 
TV Source Magazine reports season two of The Bay is free for Amazon Prime members in areas including the USA, UK-Ireland, Germany, Austria, and Japan. Non-members can purchase the entire season for $12.99, or single episodes for $1.99 via Amazon Instant Video. The Bay Season Two Trailer 
Here’s more on The Bay , from the show’s official website : 
The 2016 Emmy® winning digital drama series THE BAY follows the affluent, yet dysfunctional Bay City residents living in a town cursed by Red Garrett, an ominous senator who was murdered by his socialite granddaughter, Sara Garrett. Living in his shadow, Sara, her youngest son Pete, and those around them face a series of dilemmas involving rape, blackmail, sordid lovers, and vindictive arch rivals. Their lives riddled with sex, lies, and scandals, the town’s privileged tangle with those who confuse obsession for love, vengeance for justice, and power for success. 
What do you think? Are you a fan of The Bay TV series? Do you plan to stream season two on Amazon? Let us know, below.

posts.author: tumstead
posts.title: Amazon Greenlights Two Kids-Themed Series
posts.text:
Amazon Greenlights Two Kids-Themed Series OTT service to stream ‘Sigmund and the Sea Monsters;’ ‘Bug Diaries’ 11/29/2016 3:22 PM Eastern 
Amazon has given a greenlight to two kids-targeted series, Sigmund and The Sea Monsters and Bug Diaries , the OTT service said Tuesday. 

Sid & Marty Kroft’s Sigmund and The Sea Monsters , based on the classic Saturday morning series from the 1970’s, follows two brothers and a cousin who befriend a friendly, young sea-monster, said Amazon. 

The animated Bug Diaries is based on children’s books by author Doreen Cronin and follows a trio of slimy, crawly and buzzy bug friends whose tiny world offers up adventures. 

“We are so excited to bring this beloved series, Bug Diaries , to our customers that highlights important life lessons for our young viewers,” said Tara Sorensen, Head of Kids Programming at Amazon Studios in a statement. “We also look forward to reviving the classic Sigmund and the Sea Monsters that has a strong message of friendship.” Want to read more stories like this?

thread.title: Amazon planning a 'premium' Echo speaker with a touchscreen
thread.title_full: Amazon planning a 'premium' Echo speaker with a touchscreen

posts.title: Amazon planning a 'premium' Echo speaker with a touchscreen
posts.text: By James Walker 3 hours ago in Technology Amazon is planning an upgraded version of its popular Echo smart speaker with a large touchscreen display, according to a report today. The new device will be physically bigger and include higher-quality speakers but retain the same functionality. The more advanced Echo is being built as a response to the unexpected success of the original. Amazon also wants to secure its position as market leader against the likes of Apple and Google, Bloomberg reported today. The current Echo is based on a cylindrical design that's meant to be unobtrusive and easy to position in any room. At first glance, it resembles a regular speaker, primarily relying on voice control to interact with its smart functionality. The next-generation model will adopt a different form, according to people familiar with the matter who spoke to Bloomberg . It will be larger and tilt upwards at the top, angling a completely new seven-inch touchscreen towards where the user is standing. Improved speakers capable of producing more detailed audio will be integrated into the device, making the Echo more suitable as a sound system replacement. The new Echo will run on an optimised version of Amazon's Fire OS. The company's Alexa digital assistant will still be the main way of interacting with the speaker. Alexa will retain its current capabilities, including basic news, weather, mail and calendar functionality alongside a rapidly growing ecosystem of third-party services. It's currently unclear what the new touchscreen will be used for. One of Bloomberg's sources suggested it could act as a digital photo board while the Echo is idling, replacing the refrigerator door as a place to store reminders, images and important notes. Smart home products are being viewed as the next frontier of consumer technology but have yet to take off in a major way. Hub products like the Echo are designed to link multiple devices together, becoming a single way to interact with everything in your home. The touchscreen could also help with this, allowing the Echo to manage other devices and expose functionality that’s too complex for voice commands alone. The Echo has been one of the most successful smart home devices to date, becoming especially popular in the U.S. Its popularity has not yet been replicated by rival smart speakers and the device has gained mainstream attention. Amazon is about to be confronted by new competition though, including Google Home . The updated Echo will help to reaffirm Amazon's market dominance and allow it to improve on the current model's hardware limitations. Amazon will unveil the device during the first quarter of 2017, according to Bloomberg's sources. Pricing is expected to be higher than the current Echo but may be subject to change.

posts.title: Don't be Fooled by Amazon's 'Weak' Cyber Monday Sales - Barron's
posts.text:
Next VIEW ALL SEARCH RESULTS 
This copy is for your personal, non-commercial use only. To order presentation-ready copies for distribution to your colleagues, clients or customers visit http://www.djreprints.com. 
http://www.barrons.com/articles/dont-be-fooled-by-amazons-weak-cyber-monday-sales-1480442007 Don’t be Fooled by Amazon’s ‘Weak’ Cyber Monday Sales Amazon just doesn’t need Black Friday or Cyber Monday the way it once did. By Nov. 29, 2016 12:53 p.m. ET Text Size ENLARGE Online shopping isn’t much of a novelty anymore Photo: NICHOLAS KAMM/AFP/Getty Images 
Wall Street doesn’t think much of the early numbers for online holiday shopping, as Amazon stock has been trending lower since Thanksgiving, from $780 to a recent $766. E-commerce sales growth appears to have decelerated during the three special sale days that analysts track — Thanksgiving, Black Friday and Cyber Monday — according to estimates from Adobe.com and Instinet. For those three days, sales rose 15%, versus 18% last year, they estimate. 
But there’s reason to believe that Amazon no longer needs Black Friday and Cyber Monday the way it once did. 
Frankly, online shopping isn’t much of a novelty anymore. It’s become so easy that people are increasingly willing to make big purchases on their phones rather than surf on the computer. Mobile sales are expected to make up 36% of early-holiday shopping this year, from 31% last year. 
And those sales should sustain the holiday sales boom for the entire Christmas season, rather than just the days after Thanksgiving: “The reduced friction of an e-commerce sale is likely moving consumer holiday shopping away from a few frenzied Thanksgiving holiday days and toward a more evenly distributed timeline of purchasing behavior,” notes Instinet analyst Anthony DiClemente. 
Amazon upgraded its mobile app in time for the holidays and found more ways to get you to reach into your wallet (yoo-hoo, Alexa’s calling!), and it’s likely to keep picking up share from less agile brick and mortar competitors. MKM Partners analyst Patrick McKeever notes that Wal-Mart ’s Black Friday appears to have been a “dud.” It’s likely the big-box chain continues to lose share to Amazon, whose shares could see a boost as more holiday sales data comes out. 
Big Picture: Wall Street is too fixated on Amazon’s early-holiday sales, even as the company looks poised to take more market share.

thread.title: Amazon Web Service Partners Want More IoT Details At AWS Re:Invent
thread.title_full: Amazon Web Service Partners Want More IoT Details At AWS Re:Invent

posts.title: Amazon Web Service Partners Want More IoT Details At AWS Re:Invent
posts.text:
Printer-friendly version Email this CRN article 
At the AWS re:Invent conference, which kicks off Tuesday, Amazon Web Services (AWS) partners will keep a laser focus on the company's Internet of Things (IoT) strategy. 
Last year, AWS launched its IoT platform, which helps system integrators build and host the back-end functionality needed to power IoT applications. This year, partners want to hear more about how AWS plans to loop its broader channel into this strategy and further enhance its existing offerings. 
"I'm interested to see if AWS comments on their stance as it pertains to the channel," said Eric Rockwell, president and CIO of CentrexIT, a San Diego, Calif.-based managed services provider. "I want to hear more about the future of the AWS channel program, how they'll be tailoring that in the next two to three years." 
[Related: The Network Must Get Smarter: 8 Ways Cisco Aims To Conquer The IoT Market ] 
The AWS managed cloud platform enables customers to connect with cloud applications, and includes technologies like a set of SDK client libraries, an AWS management console and AWS IoT starter kits. 
Rockwell, whose company secures vulnerabilities in enterprise systems and vertical markets, said Amazon is actively working on looping its channel into IoT opportunities, but he would like to see specific steps for the future. 
The AWS IoT platform enables partners to use Amazon's popular, integrated services, including the company's Aurora database, Redshift analytics platform and the Kinesis streaming data platform. 
Aater Suleman, CEO of Austin, Tex.-based Flux7, said that these services make AWS IoT a particularly strong platform – especially the integration with AWS Lambda. AWS Lambda enables users to run "stateless" code on servers, meaning the code isn't wed to any particular infrastructure and it is designed to always run when triggered. That service allows users to run code for their applications without having to maintain, scale, patch or own the hardware that underpins the services they're providing via those applications. 
"AWS is a system built around individual services – not only does Lambda exist out of the box, but it works natively with IoT," he said. "If you look at the entire piece from an integration perspective, it is a holistic platform." 
Flux7 specializes in the AWS DevOps framework and offers IoT consulting services. For instance, the AWS partner worked with integrated geotechnical and geoscience company Fugro to launch an IoT-based service that improved disaster recovery, increased developer agility and sped up time to market. 
Looking forward, Suleman said he hopes to hear more announcements surrounding AWS, particularly around the tight integration of Amazon services in AWS IoT. 
"From an announcement perspective, there are numerous small improvements and integrations we're looking for," he said. "For instance, if customers don't want to use Lambda, we currently have to re-route all those requests. We want more integration options to see where we can expand our services, particularly with customers' pre-existing business processes." 
The AWS re:Invent conference kicks off Tuesday in Las Vegas.

thread.title_full: Amazon employee attempts suicide at company HQ after sending warning email to Jeff Bezos, co-workers

posts.author: Rob Thubron
posts.title: Amazon employee attempts suicide at company HQ after sending warning email to Jeff Bezos, co-workers
posts.text:
Amazon employee attempts suicide at company HQ after sending warning email to Jeff Bezos, co-workers This won't help Amazon's reputation for having a toxic work environment on Nov 29, 2016, 3:30 PM TechSpot 
Stories of Amazon’s toxic work environment have been around for years; in 2015, CEO Jeff Bezos said a damning New York Times report didn’t “describe the Amazon I know.” But it appears that the online retail giant still has problems when it comes to employee moral, after one worker jumped off a building in what police are calling a suicide attempt. 
The incident took place at about 8:45 local time at the company’s Seattle headquarters on Monday. Bloomberg reports that the man hasn’t been identified, but police said he survived the 12-story fall and was taken to a nearby hospital. 
According to a person familiar with the matter, the man had sent out an email visible to hundreds of co-workers and company boss Bezos, which criticized the way his transfer request had been handled. He wanted to be moved to a different department, but was placed on an employee improvement plan that can lead to termination if the person doesn’t quickly show signs that he or she is improving. 
The unidentified source said the man hinted in the email that he may harm himself. 
“Our thoughts are with our colleague as he continues to recover,” Amazon said in a statement. “He’s receiving some of the best care possible and we will be there to support him throughout the recovery process.” 
Last Year’s Times piece interviewed over 100 current and former Amazon employees who talked about the company’s use of cruel management practices and its lack of empathy for staff with health and family problems. The article referred to the performance improvement plan as Amazon code for “you’re in danger of being fired.” 
Amazon’s questionable attitude toward its employees isn’t limited to those in the US. A BBC investigation into one of its UK-based warehouses found workers were expected to collect orders every 33 seconds - conditions that a stress expert said could cause "mental and physical illness." Additionally, Amazon staff at four of its warehouses in Germany have gone on strike several times over pay and working conditions. Whether this latest incident results in a change to management practices remains to be seen. Related Reads

thread.title: Amazon's next Alexa device will feature a 7-inch touchscreen

posts.title: Amazon's next Alexa device will feature a 7-inch touchscreen
posts.text: Amazon's next Alexa device will feature a 7-inch touchscreen Amazon's next Alexa device will feature a 7-inch touchscreen Posted: Tags : Accessories - Accessories + Amazon - Amazon + Amazon's Alexa AI is easily one of my favorite creations of the Seattle-based company. I've been a proud owner of the original Amazon Echo since it was first made available to just Prime customers, and it's been fantastic to see how far the Alexa platform has grown and matured since its initial release. The experience of using the Echo has gotten so much more enjoyable as time has gone on, but as Alexa has grown smarter, the Echo hardware itself still leaves me wanting a bit more at times. The device itself is built like a tank, and as much as I appreciate that aspect of it, I do find myself occasionally wishing that the actual audio quality was a bit better at times. A new report from Bloomberg suggests that Amazon is currently working on another Alexa-powered device, and it's looking like it could shape up to be the best one yet. The new device is reportedly set to debut sometime in Q1 of 2017, and in addition to featuring updated speakers for all-around better audio quality, the new Alexa gadget will also come equipped with something quite special - a 7-inch touchscreen. This would result in the device being the first Echo product to feature any sort of built-in display, and it's reported that the screen will showcase information that's related to your interactions with Alexa. For example, asking for the weather would bring up a visual forecast, calling upon your calendar would showcase your upcoming appointments, etc. The positioning of the screen is also said to feature an upwards tilt, allowing for easier readability when it's placed on a counter or table. The original Amazon Echo is still the most expensive item in the company's product line at $179.99, and we should expect this new addition to cost even more thanks to the improved speakers and inclusion of the 7-inch touchscreen. Amazon has to officially comment on this unnamed device, but seeing as how it's slated to be released within the first bit of next year, we shouldn't have to wait too much longer before we get official confirmation on Amazon's most powerful Echo yet. thread.title: Amazon Redesigns Its Connected Speaker
thread.title_full: Amazon Redesigns Its Connected Speaker

posts.title: Amazon Redesigns Its Connected Speaker
posts.text:
Amazon Redesigns Its Connected Speaker (AMZN, AAPL) By Rakesh Sharma | November 29, 2016 — 3:23 PM EST 
Amazon.com Inc. ( AMZN ) is reconfiguring Alexa. 
According to a Bloomberg repor t, Amazon is adding a seven-inch touchscreen to Echo, its popular smart home device, to make it easier for users to scroll through weather forecasts, news, and calendar appointments on it. The touchscreen may also serve another purpose. A May Wall Street Journal story stated that Amazon’s Lab126 hardware unit was working on a tablet-like screen “so that users can summon Web pages, videos or images when, say, their hands are covered in flour.” 
The Bloomberg report, which cites unnamed sources, also claims that the new device’s speaker will be larger and tilt upwards to enable users to better access the new touchscreen. The screen itself may be equipped with the ability for users to physically pin photographs onto it, much like a refrigerator. The device was earlier shaped like a cylinder that featured two downward-facing speakers and seven microphones. 
Amazon’s proposed redesign occurs as the market for connected speakers is becoming crowded. Alphabet Inc. subsidiary Google ( GOOG ) released Google Home, its take on the connected speaker, in September this year. Apple Inc. ( AAPL ) is also said to be working on its own version of a connected speaker. (See also: Apple Is Building Homes With Connected Devices ). 
Google’s device has two microphones and four speakers. It has a slanted top with colorful lights that start blinking when they hear a user command. Reviewers have praised the Google device for its design and colored base. However, Amazon’s device has come out the winner in terms of functionality and ability to get things done. This is primarily because the company has added developer integration with services, such as pizza delivery, and also open-sourced its skills kit to developers. (See also: How Does Google Home Compare With Amazon's Alexa? ) 
The Seattle company has a head start in the market. In addition to selling more than five million units of its device since 2014, Amazon has also introduced variants at different price points. The Echo, Dot, and Tap speakers are priced at $180, $130, and $50. Learn how to invest by subscribing to the Investing Basics newsletter Thanks for signing up to Investing Basics.
